archetype_name: Family Weekend Showstopper: Indian Feast Night
name: Punjabi Chole with Yogurt-Fermented Bhature and Pickled Onion
description: A festival-style North Indian chickpea curry simmered with warm spices, served with puffed, yogurt-fermented bhature and bright lemon-herb garnish. Set aside time to soak beans and rest the dough for a true weekend showstopper.
prep_steps: Pick through and rinse chickpeas; cover with plenty of water and soak 8–12 hours (overnight). Drain.
Finely chop onions and garlic. Roughly chop coriander. Cut lemon into wedges.
Measure spices for chole: cumin seeds, ground cumin, coriander, turmeric powder, garam masala, chili flakes, bay leaves, cinnamon, cloves, black pepper, salt.
Make bhature dough: In a bowl, combine flour, sugar, salt, yoghurt, 1 tablespoon oil, and enough water to form a soft, slightly tacky dough. Knead 8–10 minutes until smooth.
Lightly oil the dough, cover, and rest in a warm spot 2–3 hours to gently ferment and relax.
Open diced tomatoes and set aside. Line a tray with paper towels for fried bread. Set out pickled onions and mango chutney.
cook_steps: Cook chickpeas: Add soaked chickpeas to a pot with fresh water to cover by 5 cm and a pinch of salt. Simmer on the stovetop until tender (60–90 minutes), or pressure cook until soft. Drain and reserve 1 cup cooking liquid.
Start the chole masala: Heat 3 tablespoons oil or ghee in a wide pot. Add cumin seeds, bay leaves, cinnamon, and cloves; toast 30–45 seconds until fragrant.
Add onions and a pinch of salt; cook on medium, stirring, until deep golden brown, 10–15 minutes. Add garlic; cook 1 minute.
Stir in ground cumin, coriander, turmeric powder, chili flakes, and black pepper; toast 30 seconds.
Add diced tomatoes; cook down 6–8 minutes until thick and glossy.

Add cooked chickpeas, 1/2 cup reserved cooking liquid, and garam masala. Simmer 15–20 minutes, mashing a few chickpeas with a spoon to thicken. Adjust salt and heat; add more liquid if needed for a saucy consistency.
Finish chole: Stir in chopped coriander and a squeeze of lemon. Keep warm on low.

Fry bhature: Divide rested dough into 10–12 balls. Roll each to a 15–18 cm round, 3–4 mm thick. Heat 4–5 cm oil in a deep pan to 180–185°C. Fry one round at a time, gently pressing to help puff; flip once golden (30–45 seconds per side). Drain on paper towels. Repeat.
Serve: Spoon chole into a serving bowl. Garnish with extra coriander and lemon wedges. Serve hot bhature alongside with pickled onions and mango chutney.

to bring dough together and for cooking chickpeas
